reviewText:
The 1994 gem, Raptor: Call of the Shadows, is a great game! It's classic, vertically-scrolling shoot-em-up fun with a cool arsenal of weapons. It's not particularly difficult, but knowing which weapons to use at what points to rack up maximum damage makes for some fun strategy. And the music was great, too! Still gets me pumped!

This 2015 update of an old gaming staple, though, is lazy and improves absolutely nothing about the game.

Graphically, the game is unchanged. The game is still locked to a low FPS rate, and though the resolution is configurable via the game launcher, there is no option for 1920x1080. There IS an option for a smoothing filter" though this does nothing more than muddy the whole appearance of the game.

This version also still rocks the classic
date: midi tunes that made my young boy heart thump in anticipation of my airborne battles. However
recommended: the tracks don't loop seamlessly as I recall them doing in the original iteration. There seems to be a brief pause of silence at the end of a track before it picks up again from the beginning and it's quite annoying.\n\nOnto gameplay. At its core
hoursPlayed: this version of Raptor is excatly as the original. Controller support has been implimented
voteText: but it's sub-par. I still have to grab hold of the mouse on menus to know what I'm doing. On that note
votesHelpful: when I do use the mouse
votesTotal: the on screen cursor will hit these mysterious vertical and/or horizontal "boundaries" past which cannot navigated without first giving the mouse shaking about the mouse pad. This I can't explain
votesFunny: but I've not had any similar issue with any other application on my PC.\n\nLastly
commentsCount: what has proven to be MOST troublesome about this half-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ release is the completely unintuitive management of save profiles. I'm a gamer who saves often
column16: and it wasn't long before I discovered that every time you save in this game
column17: it does NOT overwrite the previous save
column18: but instead creates ANOTHER save affiliated with the same name. Additionally
column19: there's a very limited number of available save states
column20: so if you forget to go back and delete previous saves from the main menu
column21: you could came back to the hangar after having completed a mission only to discover that you CAN'T save your progress
column22: and you can't delete previous saves without navigating back to the main menu
column23:
meaning that all progress from the previous save is inherently lost.

It's the sort of thing that makes you wonder if the developers every bothered to play their port before releasing it to the public.

I would NOT recommend this port to any person wishing to experience Raptor: Call of the Shadows. I would instead tell them install DOSBox and run the original version- it's actually a bit better.

reviewText:
Better play the old DOS version. It's a shame that they decided to use very LQ wav files as OST.

For example:

[WAV] [01:31]  - raptor2  </11 kHz/45 kbps/502,61 KB/> (Microsoft ADPCM 11025 kHz, 4 bit, Mono, 45 kbps)

You can actually replace it with a 16 bit PCM unsigned wav which sounds way better than this 4 bit crap.

I have no clue why they decided to use wave files and not the old DOS and Win9x *.mus files. It's a shame tho.

And another thing is a real shame: The framerate seems to be limited to 24 FPS.

My advice to anyone interested into this game:

Download DosBox: http://www.dosbox.com/
Download the Game (DOS): *Download link removed due to an unclear licence situation*

I also made a video comparing those two versions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h1N2z9wuzIw

And play it - you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Now before I get started I want to let everyone know, I have nothing against Raptor. I played it as a kid for hours on end and bought the 2015 edition out of nostalgia.

Everything I remember as a kid is there. The one thing I don't remember being in the 1994 release are the bugs, specifically

Buggy Mouse controls - Sometimes there is an invisible forcefield, that prevents your mouse cursor (or your plane) from being able to track across the length of the playing screen and is a problem with all screen resolutions. Now you can navigate the menus with ease with the keyboard, but when your playing the game proper, you don't want to contend with this whilst flying the plane, especially as the playing field can get pretty crowded at times.

Save Bug - Saving after each mission was never a problem playing in the original release (and essential), so imagine my horror when confronting a error message for the first time saying I need to delete some pilot saves?

I'm hoping these problems are rectified as they are annoyances to a great scrolling shoot-em-up, until then its a thumbs down for me.
voteText: 28 of 31 people (90%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I loved Raptor back in the day, and don't get me wrong it's still a serviceable shooter if not as good as in my memories, the problem is this godawful port. While I commend the effort of actually making a native Windows version of an older game rather than just tossing it running through Dosbox onto Steam like way too many publishers do, this one is unfortunately pretty botched. Sure, achievements are a nice touch, but there's inadequate options (why a max resolution of 1280x800?), the keyboard controls feel wonky, the mouse controls also feel wonky, and gods help you if you have multiple monitors since the game doesn't lock the mouse properly, meaning it can end up drifting over to another screen causing you to lose control over your ship. In this case, Dosbox might actually have been preferable.

I'd gladly give this a positive review if future patches fixed the issues with Raptor's Windows version, it's still a pretty fun game even if I've played far better shmups in the dozen years since this came out, but the egregious technical issues just ruin the experience. It's probably more playable if you're only using a single screen, but even for those people I can't give it the recommend in this state.

Edit: I've now attempted to play with a controller as well since I'd really like to be able to use this. The controller support is also broken. Wow.

reviewText:
This is definite a worth buy! I got the Shareware version of Raptor: Call of the Shadows (I call it just Raptor) back in the 90Â´s with my first PC. I donÂ´t know how long and often I played these first levels but I was so in love with this game. The graphics, the sound, the loads of weapons you can equip to your aircraft with is just amazing for an arcade shooter!

Besides the standard machine gun you can buy air/air missiles which help you to get rid of other flying metal through the stages. When it comes to tanks, ships and all other stuff thatÂ´s on the ground you better switch to air/ground missiles which are the green ones :) There are also nuclear power bombs, scanners, plasma and laser weapons available. So you see quite a choice for a shooter that comes back from the 90Â´s

Steering is quite simple - use your arrow keys for the directions, space for firing and the ALT key for switching weapons. You can configure the key mapping and even controllers are supported but ey, I played that back in 1994 with keyboard so you should stick to it! :)

The game has loads of stages I am not sure yet but I think it where 9 for each sector which is 27 levels in total. The sectors look all a little bit different, so they never get boring.

BRAVO sector offers you a vast and aried landscape, TANGO sector looks like a jungle after you beat the first wave which looks  similar to the bravo sector missions but with more concrete buildings on the ground.

The last sector is calles OUTER REGIONS which is well anywhere but not on earth I guess. These missions look like the moon, mars and other planets and have the toughest enemies this game has to offer.

I totally recommend this game if you like retro games and you can live with dated pixel graphics *yay*

5 out of 5 foxes + the retro bonus fox   6/5 foxes!!!


If you like this review please join my retro games group on steam:

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/retrogames8090

reviewText:
Please upvote this review so all the potential buyers can see.

This game is an exact copy of the original DOS game, wrapped in another application which only enables it to run on Windows. Sadly, the author shows no signs of ever fixing the bugs in this version even after being contacted by email directly. The issues in this version are:

- FPS locked at 24
- Mouse and joystick/controller issues
- Mouse controls have different speed than keyboard
- Original Raptor soundtrack was replaced by different, pretty crappy soundtrack
- Achievements don't register properly
- Save file issues
and more.

Simply said, get the original DOS game, which is also available on Steam and has none of the issues listed above:

http://store.steampowered.com/app/358360/

reviewText:
*window shopping*
New Release!
Raptor: Call of The Shadows
O.O
TAKE MY MONEY!!!

It's an old 2D vertical scroller shooter style game. The best that ever was. You're a mercenary pilot, sent on missions to other worlds in order destroy your employer's competition. You take other pilots' planes away with bullets, missiles, and/or plasma fire, then you buy more ways of taking your bullets, missiles and/or plasma bolts and putting them into enemy craft, and then you take their planes away again.
I'm not really sure what it is that makes this game so special, but I've been coming back to it over and over again since the mid 90s.
It's got a very rudimentary character creation, several constantly active (when equipped) weapons and many more selectable ones that, fairly obviously, only fire when selected, and some really fun gameplay. There's definitely some nostalgia in there too.

Two slight annoyances:
1) The mouse is really sticky for some reason. It never used to be in this game, but now the pointer will refuse to move past an apparently random point from time to time, only passing it when you swing back and forward again, as if to take a run up and break through an invisible mouse-barrier. Odd.
2) The launcher lets you pick the resolution and run in full screen, but then sticks the image in the top right corner of the screen. I can't help but think there's not much point in having a full screen option if all you're doing is giving us black space.

reviewText:
This game is the father of classic shoot'em ups, a must-have for the lovers of the genre; I remember playing this when I was 10 years old and struggling to survive against the horde of battleships from the outer regions and their deadly lasers, man those were the days.

It perfectly holds up to today's standards, the graphics which were ahead of it's time are still more than decent, it has lots of weapons to buy along the way each of which are most effective against different type of enemies (missiles that can only hit ground targets and inflict great damage upon them), homing turrets that can quickly destroy enemies without having to get close to them (but in exchange they don't target ground enemies), and many more.

The soundtrack is varied, consisting of more than 10 tracks which play depending on the level of each sector you're on, and all of them convey that die-hard feeling; you're going to blow everything up and nothing can stop you.

As for the cons, I will say that even though this is a supposed 2015 edition" it isn't any different to the 2010 edition
date: or any different to the original game for that matter; I can even go as far as to say the original 94 game was even better since this port have a couple issues which I'll quickly list below:\n\n- Save feature bug

votesHelpful: it's hard to dodge bullets and position when moving the Raptor feels like skating on ice for the first time; prepare your keyboard.\n\nOverall the game still feels like the same classic game from the 90's and I would 100% recommend it for lovers of the genre or for the people who want to check shoot-em-ups for the first time alike."

reviewText:
As a vintage player of the original DOS version of this game, I can say that I enjoyed it back then and still enjoy it now.

What really stood out to me was the resolution bump and the fixed/upgraded audio, no more explosion sound bugging out nonsense because DOS audio drivers had limited audio channels.

I would have liked some new content but either way the core game is good enough for me to recommend it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's important to understand that Raptor is a 20 year old game-- not a modern pixel-hipster homage. As such, it has issues that a lot of DOS-era games had; most notably, the framerate is just always going to be low, no matter how awesome your computer is. That's how the original was, and that's how it is now.

DotEmu has added a High Quality filter which improves the framerate (to 25~30 fps), but it muddies up the graphics, which were way ahead of their time in 1994.

The game itself is a moderately deep top-down shooter; earn money, buy upgrades between missions, move to the next level once your aircraft is suffuciently armed and armored. The upgrade mechanics are still satisfying, even after all this time.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Having never played Raptor (I've only recently heard of this game through YouTube), I can tell that for the time this was a pretty decent shooter, also unique (at the time) in that you could purchase upgrades and weapons for your plane. I HIGHLY recommend playing this game with a controller, however, as the keyboard feels awkward for me, and playing with the mouse is atrocious. Also, it would be nice if it had higher resolutions; it doesn't go up to 1600x900 (the maximum resolution for my monitor), and I'm not a fan of playing games windowed. The HQ-filter isn't that great, either. Those quibbles aside, this is a decent DOS shooter... though it won't beat Tyrian when it comes to my favorite DOS shooter.

reviewText:
This is the exact original, working on modern machines.  Working may be somewhat generous as the mouse support doesn't work properly in fullscreen mode because the mouse will seemingly randomly stop moving further right after moving the ship about 2/3 of the way to the right hand screen (windowed mode doesn't confine the mouse, so it's unplayable).

I'm not particularly interested in an HD remake of this game, it's purely nostalgia that drove this purchase, but it seems incredible to me that a twenty year old game works less well now than it did twenty years ago.

DotEmu (the dev for this) blew it, big time.

some HINTS for extra FUN

in the boardcomputer (where you choose a secor) klick the blue button, followed by all 3 dark red lamps. if they are all on (flashy red) you encounter apes throwing coconuts, crossing dinosaurs, (bravo) laserstation-cows (tango) and some very strong extra-vessles in the outer regions

reviewText: 0.1 hours played at the time of writing this review. That doesn't matter because Raptor: Call of the Shadows was a game that I spent countless hours of my misspent youth playing, regardless of what Steam reports. This game is good, hands down, just take my word for it. This was the bomb back when I was just a 7 year old kid with nothing but a 486 and a lot of time (and baddies) to kill. When I didn't feel like playing my Sega Genesis, this is what I escaped to. Okay, enough nostalgia, phew.\n\nRaptor with it's stylized 2-D graphics and soundblaster tunes is a perfect pair of beauty and violent devastation. The customization choices of one of the most lethal and creative arsenal ever, is at your disposal. One particular thing I loved about this game is the amount of detail that went into each mission of the game, for a game originally released in 1994, Raptor was nothing short of an amazing, action-packed experience; To me it still is, to you, it definitely can be.

what are you looking for here? honestly you are looking for a review??? this game does not even need one, it is my childhood and i am sure everyone who was born in 1990s should have played this too but here is a little review for other developers and people who are wondered what this game is:

it does not have frost bite engine but it has fully destructive world

it does not have super graphics but there is no graphic glitches

it does not have season pass or DLC but it has 3 episodes with 9 levels each

it does not have microtransactions but you can upgrade your jet with what you earn in game

it does not even have a trailer, it was never announced in E3 but every true gamer knows it

it does not cost $60 but back in 1990s there was a freeware version of this game (still exists) and it is like demo which gives you access to episode 1 completely

final verdict: you see now? this game is much more completed for $5 than any other $60 game out there which givse you only half of the game and rest is DLC.

reviewText:
Similar to DOS version except for some VERY IMPORTANT differences!
- Pressing F10 to refil your shields & give you a Deathray has been removed
- Saving your game creates a new save file so you'll end up with multiple copies of your current profile. Saved each level? good luck finding the recent one!
- Mouse speed is dependant on your Windows Cursor speed. Sometimes it's higher. Sometimes it doesn't reach all the menu items; fixed by moving into opposite screen edge for a bit.

Other than those 3, the new stuffs are minor.
- Explosions have more particles, like fireworks.
- Music may be very slightly different but sounds exactly the same. They are .wav files instead of the built-in midi, so you can replace them with some actual remastered ones from Youtube.
- You can choose between 640 x 400 or 960 x 600 resolutions. Again, both look identical. Don't load Fullscreen through the Loader else the game may look stretched. Load it Windowed, then press Alt+Enter.
- Includes a High-Quality filter, which essentially blurs everything.

While Raptor is an excellent game, this 'Enhanced' version doesn't need DOSbox, that's really it, so don't buy it if you can find the DOS version. Maybe pick it up though so you can proudly say that you've bought it.

reviewText:
Chances are, if you're here, you know what this game is already, you remember the long nights trying to save up for that auto-gun upgrade, or challenging yourself to destroy every building on a level.

This is the game, and it is finally available for standalone purchase, without having to buy all those other Apogee games. At $5 normal retail, this isn't a bad deal for a game. No, it's not remastered, and the HD filter really doesn't do anything for actual graphics, but if you're a true fan of this game, 3d rendering doesn't mean â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in comparison to fun gameplay, which is why you should pick this dang game up.

If you aren't familiar with Raptor, this is an old-school shoot em up, one of the the first available for PC in the early 90's. It features the ability to accumulate points, that also act as your cash. You can use the cash to purchase ship upgrades, such as missiles, or auto-attacking guns to make some levels more manageable. The levels are fairly quick, but very replayable to find secrets, or accumulate more cash.

True vets to the bullet hell games will find this one a little easier to play, especially compared to japanese games in the same genre, but veteran mode can pose a challenge. I remember beating this game; the excitement put the first pube on my balls, and ever since then, I felt vindicated as a gamer.

Give this game a try if you have an extra $5, but don't you dare pass it up if it's on sale.

reviewText:
Oh man, I was so happy to see this somewhere beside the dusty old box of floppy disks sitting in the corner of my closet.

Raptor is a vertical shooter of the sort that anyone who played arcade games in the 1990s will be familiar with. You shoot enemies, get money, upgrade your ship, collect powerups, and fight bosses.

It's pretty simple, but alot more challenging than I remember. There's probably a good dozen hours worth of gameplay here unless you're much better than I am. Check out some gameplay videos if you're not nostalgic, even though this has aged well, gaming has come a long ways.

reviewText: Erm......So, what's so 2015 about this edition? I can understand that a full-fledged HD remake might be asking a bit much, but I'll take any actual improvements and modernizations I can get. I'd settle for a remastered soundtrack. But really, the only thing we get is an HQ filter" that marginally improves the visuals. I'll be honest though
date: I only bought this release because I pirated the 2010 version
recommended: and I felt bad about it.\n\nOn to the actual game. If you've never played Raptor Call of the Shadows
hoursPlayed: it's a classic shoot-em-up that existed before today's bullet hells that permeate the genre with the likes of Cave and Treasure's offerings
voteText: etc. This means there's actually a reasonable amount of munitions being fired at you at any given time
helpfulPercent: with exception to some boss fights in the later difficulties.\n\nThe game is split up into three zones
votesTotal: for 27 levels total. In between levels you can buy weapons and consumables from a shop with money you earn by shooting down enemies and destroying parts of the environment.  These weapons add variety to your arsenal from your standard air-to-air rockets all the way up to death lasers. These weapons are selectable during the mission
votesFunny: so you can adjust for various situations on the fly. However
commentsCount: having to cycle through all these weapons to use the one you want can be frustrating
column16: so I recommend you only keep weapons you actually need and sell the rest.\n\nA few things the game does well includes a nice
column19: and there's a nice degree of progression. The soundtrack deserves its own mention
column22: the sound rendering is such that lots of action can cause the music to muffle or jitter.\n\nIf you're using a gamepad
column23: you'll need to reconfigure the defaults right away. The only button mapped correctly is the shot button. You'll have to use bombs and change weapons using the keyboard until you make corrections. Also
column25: use the Enter key on the keyboard
column26: then push the button on the gamepad. Otherwise your mapping won't work for some reason.\n\nHere's the breakdown: if you already own Raptor in one incarnation or another
column27: the 2015 release is not worth a purchase. However
column28: for those just now discovering this title
column29: it's a fun game that is completely worth an insta-buy."

reviewText: Couldnt decide to give this a positive or negative review. It brings back memories of my childhood playing it. I really enjoy the game. Though the saves get annoying having to delete them in order to save again, though its not that much of a hassle. Just go and delete a few saves before and after you start, but dont save after each sector or you'll reach that limit quickly. And the invisible verticle and horizontal mouse barriers get annoying when playing with the mouse. In game its not too bad, except for the far right side. But its exceptionally bad in the hangar when purchasing and selling weapons. You have to keep circling the mouse along the edges of the screen to have it move further depending on where the invisible barrier was. And some of the achievements are broken and wont activate.  Overall if you can deal with those problems, its still a great game.

reviewText: This release has two oddities that make it inferior to the original/GoG version. One is that it has poor mouse support, meaning you'll get stuck on invisible walls and move slower as you approach the edges of the screen. The other is that saves are very poorly implemented, causing the game to fill its limited save slots through normal play. You'll have to clear out your old save data manually after a few saves to free up space.\n\nEven if you play using the keyboard, the minor graphic improvements aren't worth the hassle of manually managing your save data. Buy the GoG version instead.

reviewText: Raptor: Call of Your Childhood is a game that will appeal to all those who enjoyed playing this game when they were younger. Now Nostalgia factor aside it hasn't aged well, yet is still a challenging and enjoyable shoot em up experience. The customization is a nice feature, as is the shop and shields setup for health. The game plays well and is graphically beautiful given its time, albeit the music is atrocious (I don't even recall it being as bad as it is). Still worth the money for anyone wanting a trip down memory lane, and for those uninitiated, is still an enjoyable experience and exposure to games of PC gaming past.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
While Raptor: Call of the Shadows itself is a fun game, the '15 version is the weaker than the '94 version. The '15 version actually feels like a down grade from the '94 version and seems like a quick cash grab for DotEmu (whoever DotEmu is). The 5 things that seperate this version from the '94 version are the music has slightly changed, some of the enemy ships have an added firework animation when they are destroyed, mouse support, steam cloud and achievements, and  bugs.

Bugs I've found:

Your jet moves slower than it does in the '94 version and doesn't keep up with the mouse if you are playing with the mouse.

When you save your game, it creates a new save file rather than saving over the file you are already playing on.

You can't skip the opening cut scene or the death cut scene.

The mouse cursor won't go all the way to the right of the screen in some menus unless you move the mouse all the way to the left first.

I would recomend you get the '94 version of Raptor over this version as it is the same exact price, does not have any of the above mentioned bugs, and the music sounds better.

reviewText:
Wow!! I was really surprised when this game finally arrived on Steam! Man, I've been looking for this game a long, long while. Just having played the demo version, I've even played DOS games like Tyrian, Jazz Jackrabbit, & Wacky Wheels all from Shareware versions from early to late 90's. Raptor even though was just a demo, kept me coming back replaying it over & over! So finally I bought the full version on Steam!!
The features I love in this game are the ability to buy, sell, & upgrade with different items, weapons, & shields. Also earn credits as you progress thru each stage. When you complete a sector, your credits can be carried over to the next sector. There are 3 Sectors: Bravo, Tango, & Outer Regions. The 1st two sectors have 9 stages each. I haven't tried Outer Regions yet so IDK how many stages there are. Still I'm loving this game so far even if it's challenging!! I highly recommend this game to hardcore & shoot'em up fans!! :)
Graphics: 4.75/5, Gameplay: 5/5, Sound: 4.5/5, Replay Value: 5/5. Overall: 5/5!! :)

reviewText: Not much different from the original version except for a little better looking visuals. Same basic game which I wasn't to impressed with. Old school shmups I tend to like are more in line with 1942 style. This has some good qualities just feels stiff and not really that fun. Just can't recommend it.

reviewText: I love this game but I can't recommend the 2015 edition. The music quality is worse and the frame rate is lower than in the original DOS version. Also, every time you save, a new copy of your pilot is saved and an additional save file is created instead of just updating your pilots current save state. The Steam achievements are pretty lame and make no sense (i.e. there is an achievement for giving the pilot a certain name). Some of them are even buggy and won't unlock the way they should. The mouse controls are also a bit dodgy. Sometimes the mouse gets stuck on a certain horizontal position. Don't spend money on this lackluster port. Get the classic version (runs on DOSBox) which is also available here on Steam.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Over twenty years old, but still a great shooter game after all those years. It has everything it needs for this type of game. If you like classical Shoot'Em Up games this is for you. Fun and motivating. Definitely worth a buy. The 2015 Edition adds Steam Achievements. Graphics can be improved with a HQ Filter (then the game looks slightly different than in the screenshots). The game works fine with a gamepad. There are three different zones with nine levels each (27 levels total). The game becomes quite a challenge if you don't find a way to collect money and upgrade your ship (18 items available in the shop). Collecting items and selling them in the shop will help you out (the only time you can't use a controller is for selling, you need the mouse). You can buy up to five shields, there are different weapons available for air and ground targets (or against both). Some of the weapons are always equipped, others you can switch during combat. A little bit annoying are the limited savegame slots (you have to delete old savegames first) and that you can't really distinguish them (no titles, no dates). I owned this game back in the 90s but never really played it (I think it was a shareware version just with Bravo sector levels). When I was buying it for Steam I didn't even think I would play it for hours, really a great classic game that, playing it for several hours now, exceeded my expectations, addicting gameplay. I think you can have up to ten hours of casual fun with this game to play it through and unlock the achievements.
